Chapter on Characteristics, Chapter 4. The treatise states:
How can the characteristics of this consciousness be seen?
In brief, there are three kinds:
First, establishing its intrinsic nature; second, establishing its causal nature; third, establishing its resultant nature.
Among them, the Älaya consciousness is its intrinsic nature, because it is the cause for the arising of all defiled dharmas, as it holds the seeds in association with them.
Among them, the causal nature refers to all defiled dharmas, as this Älaya consciousness is the cause for the arising of all seeds at all times.
Among them, the establishment of its resultant nature means that this Älaya consciousness arises due to the power of the perfuming of all defiled dharmas since beginningless time.
The commentary states:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

By these different names, the Älaya consciousness is explained. Since its characteristics are not yet known in these different explanations, the characteristics of the Älaya consciousness itself, its causal characteristics, its resultant characteristics, and so forth are explained.

Among them, the characteristic of the Älaya consciousness itself is that it is the condition for the perfuming of all defiled dharmas, and the consciousness has the superior power to produce them. This shows that the essence of the consciousness has this power.

The characteristic of holding seeds in association means that after being perfumed by all defiled dharmas, it becomes the cause for the production of those dharmas, and is therefore said to hold seeds.

Because those perfuming activities are combined with that superior power, it is called association. This characteristic of the Älaya consciousness itself, after being perfumed by all defiled dharmas, becomes the cause for their production.
The consciousness that holds seeds in association becomes the cause for the production of those defiled dharmas after being perfumed by them and acquiring superior power.
This is the causal characteristic of the Älaya consciousness.

In this passage, beginning with the establishment of the result characteristic up to the statement due to the power of beginningless perfuming, it means that when dharmas have been perfumed, this consciousness is born, and it includes and holds beginningless perfuming, so it is called the result characteristic.
Chapter on Perfuming, Chapter on Perfuming, Chapter 5, the treatise says:
Next, what is perfuming?
What is this perfuming called?
It is born together with and ceases together with those dharmas, and then becomes the cause for the birth of those dharmas. This is the meaning of the basis.

It is like sesame being perfumed by flowers. The sesame is born together with and ceases together with the flowers. Because there is the cause for the birth of the fragrance of those flowers in the sesame, it can produce fragrance.
It is also like the perfuming of desire and so forth. Desire and so forth are born together with and cease together with the mind, and then become the cause for the birth of desire and so forth.

It is also like the case of one who has heard much, whose mind is born and perishes together with the mind that thinks about what has been heard, and which has already become the cause for the arising of that [mind], because it is the cause for the arising of that [mind]. Due to the perfuming of grasping and holding, it is called one who upholds the Dharma.
One should know that the Älaya consciousness has this principle.
The commentary says:
The Dharma refers to the previously mentioned defiled dharmas.
Having been born and perished together, it later becomes the cause for their arising means that it again becomes the essence of the cause for those defiled dharmas.
Chapter on Non-Unitary and Non-Different. Chapter Six. The treatise states:
Next, are the seeds of those defiled dharmas in the Älaya consciousness distinguished and separate, or are they undifferentiated?

There is no separate substance that abides in the consciousness, nor is it not different. However, the Älaya consciousness arises in this way, having a superior ability to give rise to those dharmas, and is called the consciousness with all seeds.
The commentary says:
Are the seeds of those defiled dharmas in the Älaya consciousness distinguished or undistinguished?
If so, what is the error?
If these seeds have distinctions, then the Älaya consciousness would also have distinctions.
Moreover, the meaning of the momentary cessation of the Älaya consciousness would not be established, because of the distinctions.
Moreover, the perfuming of good and evil dharmas would immediately become the substance of good and evil seeds, but this is indeterminate.
If there are no distinctions, how can it be said to be many?
This meaning is not established.
Therefore, both have errors.

The phrase there is no separate substance abiding in consciousness, nor is it not different, up to being called the consciousness with all seeds means that the words neither separate nor not separate are used to avoid the errors mentioned above.
The phrase arises like this means arising according to its kind.
The ability to produce them is because when defiled dharmas are produced, they are associated with the ability.
It is also said that because it has the ability to produce them, it is called the consciousness that contains all seeds.
There is a simile here: just as a wheat seed has the ability to produce a sprout and is therefore called a seed.
If it is old or damaged by fire, the ability to produce wheat is destroyed.
The form of the wheat remains as before, but because its power is destroyed, it is no longer a seed.
The Älaya consciousness is also like this. It has the ability to produce all dharmas and is therefore called the consciousness that contains all seeds because it is associated with that ability.
Chapter 7: Mutual Causality of the Six Consciousnesses, Treatise:
Next, how can the Älaya consciousness and the defiled dharmas be seen as mutually causing each other simultaneously?
It is like a burning lamp: the flame and wick are mutually caused by the burning simultaneously.
It is also like a bundle of reeds supporting each other, not falling simultaneously.
Consciousness and dharmas are also like this, mutually being causes for each other, you should know.
Just as it is established that the Älaya consciousness is the cause of defiled dharmas, defiled dharmas are also the cause of the Älaya consciousness, because no other causes can be found.
The commentary says:
Moreover, the Älaya consciousness and defiled dharmas simultaneously mutually serve as causes for each other.
How can this be seen? It is shown through analogy.
It is just like a burning lamp: the flame and the wick mutually serve as causes for each other in a single moment.
Because it relies on the wick, the flame is able to arise, and the wick becomes the cause for the flame's arising;
that very moment of flame is able to burn the wick, and the flame becomes the cause for the wick's burning.
This illustrates the meaning of co-existent cause, because the effect is seen to arise only when the cause is present.

From the Älaya consciousness as the cause of defiled dharmas, the defiled dharmas are also the cause of the Älaya consciousness. This is so until other conditions cannot be found. This statement shows that the Älaya consciousness and the defiled dharmas are mutually causal, and also shows the principle of causality.
Chapter 8: Distinguishing the Difference and Non-Difference of Cause and Effect. The treatise says:
How can perfuming be without difference and various, yet be the cause for dharmas with difference and various distinctions?
It is like various knots in a cloth, at the time they are not seen as various;
but once they enter the dyeing vat, then there are innumerable various colors and patterns manifested on the cloth.
The Älaya consciousness is also like this. When it is perfumed by various perfuming, at the time of perfuming there is no difference;
but once the fruit of perfuming is manifested, then there are innumerable various distinctions.
The commentary says:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
How can perfuming be without difference and without various kinds, yet be the cause for the arising of differences and various kinds? This principle is illustrated by analogy.
Just as when a cloth is tied with many threads, no various appearances can be seen;
but once it is placed in a dyeing vessel, then various appearances can be seen.
The Älaya-vijÃ±Äna is also like this. The cloth is like the arising of the fruit, and the dyeing vessel is like the ripening of the fruit, so it is called the arising fruit.
Placing in the dyeing vessel means being grasped by conditions.

At the time of perfuming, there are no various kinds, but when it reaches the time of the fruit, it becomes the cause for the manifestation of innumerable appearances and the essence of various dharmas, like a cloth that has been dyed.
Chapter on Dependent Origination, Chapter 9 of the Treatise says:
This dependent origination is the most subtle and profound in the MahÄyÄna.
In brief, there are two kinds of dependent origination:
1. The aspect of self-nature, and 2. The aspect of what is desirable and undesirable.
Among them, due to the Älaya consciousness, dharmas arise. This is the arising of the self-nature part, because it serves as the condition for the various parts of the self-nature.

There is also the twelve-linked dependent arising, which is the part of love and non-love, serving as the condition for the various bodies of good destinies, evil destinies, the lovable, and the unlovable.
The commentary says:
This is the most subtle and profound in the Mahayana. Because ordinary beings cannot understand it, it is subtle.
Because arhats and others cannot fathom it, it is profound.
The brief explanation of the two kinds is the establishment of the self-nature part and the part of love and non-love. Because these two kinds of dependent arising are named and explained.
Due to the Älaya consciousness means that because the Älaya consciousness is the cause, dharmas are able to arise. This is called the self-nature part.
Because it serves as the cause for the various kinds of bodies.
If it is said to be ignorance and so forth, this is the part of love and non-love.
Why is it so?
Because it is the cause of various loved and unloved body parts.
The treatise says:

If one is confused about the first dependent arising in the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna, one may either grasp intrinsic nature as the cause, or past karma as the cause, or the transformation of the god ÄªÅ›vara as the cause, or the self as the cause, or no cause and condition.
Moreover, if one is confused about the second dependent arising, one grasps the self as the doer and experiencer.
It is like a group of many congenitally blind men who have never seen an elephant, or someone shows them an elephant.
Some touch the elephant's trunk, some touch its tusks, some touch its ears, some touch its tail, some touch its legs, and some touch its back.
Someone asks them:
What is the elephant like?
Or they answer:
It is like a plow handle, like a pestle, like a winnowing basket, like a wooden barrel, like a broom, or like a stone mountain. They speak like this.

Thus, those born blind who do not understand the two kinds of dependent origination and ignorance grasp at intrinsic nature, or say it is due to past actions, or say it is the transformation of an independent creator, or say it is created by a self, or say it is without a cause, or grasp at an agent, or grasp at an experiencer. Because they do not recognize the essence, cause, and effect of the Älaya consciousness, it is like not recognizing the whole elephant.

In brief, the Älaya consciousness is the consciousness of karmic retribution and the consciousness of all seeds. This is its essence. Because it includes all bodies in the three realms and all destinies.
The commentary says:
As for those who say past actions are the cause, it is because they do not accept that there is the power of present human effort as a cause.
Such beings born blind are used as a metaphor.
As for those born blind due to ignorance, it refers to the initial ignorance in the twelve links of dependent origination. Because of ignorance, they are called born blind.

Because they do not understand the nature, causal characteristics, and resultant characteristics of the Älaya consciousness means that the nature of the Älaya consciousness as previously established is called the nature, the causal characteristics as established are called the causal characteristics, and the resultant characteristics as established are called the resultant characteristics. They do not understand this.
Because of the power of ignorance, they do not understand the nature of the Älaya consciousness itself, and thus grasp the five causes such as self-nature as the causes of all dharmas.
Because they do not understand the second aspect of what is desirable and undesirable, they grasp the self as the doer and experiencer.
Among them, the cause refers to the perfuming of all dharmas, which exists within the Älaya consciousness.
The result refers to the very consciousness perfumed by all dharmas, which is the consciousness of karmic retribution with all its seeds.
Its nature is called the result because it is named the result due to the maturation of the body it obtains.
The seeds of all dharmas refer to the perfuming that is already named the seeds.
All destinies refer to the five destinies.
All bodies refers to the various bodies of the same and different kinds within each realm.
Having already explained that the Älaya consciousness is the seed of all dharmas, in order to clarify the nature of those seeds, a verse is shown.
The treatise states:
There is a verse here:
The two of external and internal, the unclear, the worldly, and the ultimate truth,
All these seeds should be known as being of six kinds:
Instantly and simultaneously existing, and turning together with them,
Determinate and dependent on conditions, and also producing their own fruits,
Firm, indeterminate, and able to be perfumed, and combining with the perfumer,
Different from this, they cannot be perfumed - this is the characteristic of perfuming.
The six consciousnesses have no combination of characteristics, and the three differences are contradictory,
Two moments do not exist simultaneously, and the rest of the births should be the same.
These external and internal seeds have arising and also attraction,
Withered and dead due to the cause of attraction, the body perishes at the end.
The commentary says:
The two verses beginning with external and internal illustrate this.
Among them, the external refers to grain seeds, etc., and the internal refers to the Älaya consciousness.
As for unclear, the external seeds are indeterminate in meaning.
As for two, the Älaya consciousness can be wholesome or unwholesome.
There is another interpretation:
Taking defiled and pure as the two.
As for worldly, external dharmas are only called seeds in the world.
Why is it so?
It is also because of the transformation of the Älaya consciousness.
As for ultimate, only the Älaya consciousness is the seed of those dharmas.
These seeds of dharmas are of six kinds.
As for momentary, these two kinds of seeds arise and perish without interval.
If they were permanent, they could not be seeds, because at all times they would be no different from the original.
Co-existent means not past, not future, not in a separate place.
If at this time there is a seed, then at this time the fruit arises.
That which accompanies it means that the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna accompanies it until the antidote arises, and the external seeds accompany it until the roots are destroyed and the fruits ripen.
Determinate means that because the seeds are determinate, not everything can arise.
Everything that can arise has its own determination. If this seed, then this thing arises.
Dependent on conditions means that not everything arises at all times.
In whatever place and at whatever time the conditions for arising are obtained, then in that place and at that time it arises.
Also, it produces its own fruit means that its own seeds can produce its own fruits.
For example, the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna produces the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna itself, and grains produce grains themselves.
In this way, the six kinds illustrate the meaning of seeds producing fruits.
The characteristics of this perfuming will now be revealed.
The solid means that because of solidity it can be perfumed.
Unlike wind, which moves and cannot hold perfuming, because perfuming cannot follow the wind and reach a yojana.
If oil is perfumed by champak flowers, the fragrant wind will reach a hundred yojanas away.
The indeterminate means the indeterminate nature.
Like garlic, which cannot be perfumed because it is foul-smelling.
Fragrance is also like this, because it cannot be perfumed.
If an indeterminate thing, then it can be perfumed.
The perfumable means that if a thing can be perfumed, then it receives perfuming, not that which cannot be perfumed, like gold, silver, stone, etc., which are all unperfumable.
If it can hold perfuming, then it can be perfumed, referring to clothes, etc., which are perfumable things.
The conjoined with the perfumer means that if it is conjoined, then it can be perfumed, not that which is not conjoined.
Conjoined means that there is no interval between the co-arising.

If it is different, it cannot be perfumed. Different means different from the Älaya consciousness. This different consciousness cannot receive perfuming, because apart from the Älaya consciousness, other consciousnesses cannot be perfumed.

Because this Älaya consciousness possesses characteristics such as momentariness, etc., that is, because it ceases moment by moment, because it exists together with the arising consciousnesses, and so on, up to because it continues to evolve along with the various states of life until the path of cultivation arises, because it definitely serves as the cause of good, evil, etc., and because it ripens the actions of merit, demerit, and immobility in accordance with conditions in good and evil destinies.
Because the Älaya consciousness is associated with such functions, it can receive perfuming and must be established.
The arising consciousnesses are not in accord with reason.
There is no association of the six consciousnesses, because the consciousnesses move and change.
Third, there is contradiction in their different characteristics, because each consciousness arises based on its own support, each has its own object, and each has its own attention.
There is another meaning:
That is, because the characteristics of the various consciousnesses are different.
The proponents of the analogy say that the previous moment of acquisition perfumes the subsequent moment.
In order to refute this meaning,
the treatise states:
Two moments do not occur simultaneously, there is no meaning of two moments arising together.
If [two moments] are born together and perish together, then perfuming can be established.
If it is said that although they do not merge, the consciousnesses that are produced are of the same kind, and therefore they can perfume each other, then other kinds of birth should be the same.

That is to say, the various specific characteristics should also be able to be so. For example, the eyes and other faculties, which all have pure form as their characteristics, should be able to perfume each other.
It should be said like this:
Because the pure form of the eye faculty and the pure form of the ear are of the same kind, those pure forms should be able to perfume each other.
Although pure form is the same, the locations are different. If it is said that they do not perfume each other, then although consciousness is of the same kind, how can it perfume each other?
As they say, there are two kinds of seeds, namely external and internal, which both have the cause of birth and the cause of attraction.
As for the generative cause of external seeds, it lasts until the fruit ripens.
As for the generative cause of internal seeds, it lasts until the end of life.
As for the attracting cause of external seeds, it lasts from ripening until planting.
As for the attracting cause of internal seeds, it lasts after death for the corpse.
It is due to the attracting cause that [seeds] last for a long time.
If these two kinds of seeds only have a generative cause, then once separated from that cause they should perish, and there is no meaning of a long-lasting continuity.
If it is said that it is because of the transmission of moments, with the previous moment being the cause for the subsequent moment, then there would be no time of cessation;
but since there is cessation, one should know that there must be an attracting cause.
As for the attracting cause of these two kinds of seeds, it is like the cause for an arrow to travel far when drawn back on a bow.
The treatise states:
These internal seeds are unlike external seeds, and therefore another verse is spoken:
External seeds are without perfuming, but internal seeds are not so.
Without perfuming from hearing, etc., the arising of fruits is not reasonable.
The errors of loss and gain in what is done and not done,
External seeds are conditioned by the internal, and because of internal perfuming, they arise.
Furthermore, one should know that the other arising consciousnesses are the enjoyers in all bodies and destinies.
The commentary says:
Among them, the enjoyers in all bodies and destinies means that because of enjoying birth in them,
Because of enjoying existence, they are called enjoyers.
This meaning is shown by the scriptures of the MadhyÄntavibhÄga.
The treatise says:
As the MadhyÄntavibhÄga says.
The first is the consciousness with objects, the second is the consciousness of enjoyment,
The various mental factors support it, and it discriminates this enjoyment.
The commentary says:
These two consciousnesses also mutually become causes and effects.
The scriptures refer to the verses of the Abhidharma sÅ«tras.
The treatise says:
These two kinds of consciousness are also reciprocal conditions for each other. As a verse from the Abhidharma-sÅ«tra says:
All dharmas abide in consciousness, consciousness also abides in dharmas,
Each is a cause for the other, and they are also always reciprocal fruits.
The commentary says:
As for each is a cause for the other, the Älaya consciousness is at all times the cause for the arising of all dharmas.
As for they are also always reciprocal fruits, if the Älaya consciousness is the cause, then all dharmas are the fruit. If all dharmas are the cause, then the Älaya consciousness is the fruit.
Chapter on the Four Conditions, Chapter Ten of the Treatise says:
In the first dependent arising, dharmas and consciousness are reciprocal conditions. In the second dependent arising, what other conditions are there?
They are the dominant conditions.
Moreover, how many conditions do these six consciousnesses arise from?
They are the dominant condition, the object condition, and the immediate condition.

These three kinds of dependent origination, namely, the endless cycle of birth and death, the distinction between what is desirable and undesirable, and the enjoyment of the destinies, are all endowed with four conditions.
The commentary says:

As for the statement that these three kinds of dependent origination, namely, the endless cycle of birth and death, the distinction between what is desirable and undesirable, and the enjoyment of the destinies, are all endowed with four conditions, in the first kind of dependent origination, the Älaya consciousness and the dharmas perfumed by it are the causal condition.
In the second kind of dependent origination, ignorance and so forth are the dominant condition, because due to the dominance of ignorance, karmic formations can arise and so forth.
Furthermore, the six kinds of consciousness are called the dependent origination of enjoyment, and they are endowed with three kinds of dependent origination.

Among them, the dominant condition of visual consciousness is the eye, the condition as object is form, and the condition as immediate antecedent is the immediately preceding consciousness that arises in sequence.
If the preceding consciousness does not relinquish its place, then the subsequent consciousness cannot arise.
The same is the case with the other consciousnesses such as the auditory consciousness and so forth.ğŸ”½Chapter 11: The Afflictive Hindrances
The treatise states:

Thus the name and characteristics of the Älaya consciousness are established. How can it be known that only the Älaya consciousness has such a name and characteristics, and not the evolving consciousnesses?

If the Älaya consciousness that is to be established is excluded, then both impurity and purity cannot be established, namely, the impurity of the passions, the impurity of karma, and the impurity of birth cannot be established, and mundane and supramundane purity also cannot be established.
Why is the impurity of the passions not established?

Because the seeds perfumed by the passions and secondary passions in the group of the six consciousnesses are not established.ğŸ”½For example, the eye consciousness is born and perishes along with the passions and secondary passions such as craving, and it is perfumed by them to form seeds, not the others.ğŸ”½When the eye consciousness perishes, the other consciousnesses that intervene cannot be perfumed, nor can they be the support of the perfuming. Because they do not exist.
The eye consciousness having perished, the other consciousnesses that intervene are not born with craving, because they are past. Therefore this is not established.
Just as the ripening of past karma does not arise when it is already extinguished.
Moreover, the perfuming of the eye consciousness that arises together with desire is not established.
This perfuming also does not exist in desire, because desire relies on consciousness and does not firmly abide.
It also does not exist in other consciousnesses, because the various consciousnesses have separate bases and do not share the same arising and ceasing.
It also does not exist in the self-nature, because the self-nature has no two consciousnesses arising and ceasing together.
Therefore, the perfuming of the eye consciousness by the afflictions and secondary afflictions such as desire is not established.
The perfuming of consciousness by consciousness is also not established, just like the eye consciousness;
The remaining evolving consciousnesses are also not established, as should be understood according to their corresponding [characteristics].
The commentary says:

Thus, the various names of the Älaya consciousness and its characteristics have been established. Now, in order to establish these two in the Älaya consciousness and not in other consciousnesses, the principle is shown.

For example, when eye consciousness arises and ceases together with afflictions such as desire, it is precisely this eye consciousness that becomes perfumed and forms the seeds, not the others. Among them, precisely this refers to eye consciousness.
Those refers to greed and so forth.
Forming seeds means becoming a cause.ğŸ”½Not the others means not the ear consciousness and so forth.
The others that are heard refers to the ear consciousness and so forth.
Perfuming means the habitual tendencies of greed and so forth.
The basis of perfuming refers to eye consciousness.
Arising together with greed means arising simultaneously with greed and so forth. Because it is past, it cannot be a cause.
Just as past karma cannot produce results again, this is also not possible.
There are also VaibhÄá¹£ika masters who make this assertion:
They want past to exist.
However, that which is past only has a name, and the meaning it refers to cannot be obtained.
Why is it so?
If a dharma exists, how can it be past?
Therefore, their assertion of the effect is not established, because there is no perfuming.
Moreover, the perfuming of eye consciousness born together with desire is not established. This means that this eye consciousness born together with desire
itself cannot be perfumed. How can it hold the perfuming and give rise to desire, etc.?
It is also not in desire. This means that the perfuming of eye consciousness in desire does not have the meaning of being established.
Why is it so?
Because desire relies on eye consciousness, and because it does not firmly abide.
It is also not in the other consciousnesses. This means that ear consciousness, etc., are not established because of the difference in support.

Precisely because of the difference in support, there cannot be the same arising and ceasing. Eye consciousness itself relies on the eye, ear consciousness itself relies on the ear, and so on up to mental consciousness itself relying on the mental faculty.
Because each has a different location, the perfuming of one consciousness cannot be that of another consciousness.
Also, it does not exist in its own substance. This means that eye consciousness cannot perfume that eye consciousness itself, because two eye consciousnesses do not arise simultaneously.
Since there are not two consciousnesses arising together, there is no simultaneous arising and ceasing.

For this reason, the perfuming of desire and other afflictions and secondary afflictions in eye consciousness is not established, and even the perfuming of eye consciousness by eye consciousness cannot be established.
The treatise states:

Furthermore, when the first consciousness tainted by afflictions and secondary afflictions arises in this realm for one falling from the heavens of non-perception, it arises without seeds, because both perfuming and support have already passed away and do not exist.
The commentary explains:
First means the consciousness that arises first.
Arises without seeds means arising without a cause.
Perfuming and support refers to the habitual tendencies of mind and afflictions.
The treatise states:
Furthermore, when the consciousness that counteracts afflictions arises, all worldly consciousnesses cease.

If there were no Älaya consciousness, the seeds of the passions and secondary passions would not be possible in the consciousness that opposes them, and liberation would not be able to coexist with the passions and be extinguished together with them.

If at a later time a worldly consciousness is born, the mind free from desire would not exist, and its support and perfuming would long since have ceased. If, apart from the Älaya consciousness, there were no seeds from which it could be born,
Therefore, apart from the Älaya consciousness, the passions and secondary passions are not possible.
The commentary explains:
When the consciousness that opposes the passions is born, all worldly consciousnesses cease, that is, the six consciousnesses cease.

The seeds of the passions and secondary passions are not possible in the consciousness that opposes them, that is, because the consciousness that opposes them is the cause, it is not possible for worldly consciousnesses to be born.
At a later time means after the supramundane mind.
Support and perfuming means that the support is consciousness, and perfuming is perfuming by the passions and secondary passions.
Those without seeds refer to those apart from the Älaya consciousness that arise without a cause.
Among them, afflictions are precisely defilements. For this reason, the defilement of afflictions cannot be established.
Chapter 12: On the Defilement of Karma. The treatise states:
How is the defilement of karma not established?
Because the condition of karmic formations on consciousness is not established, the condition of grasping on existence is also not established.
The commentary explains:
Now, it is further shown how the defilement of karma is not established.
How is it not established?
Because the condition of karmic formations on consciousness is not established, the condition of grasping on existence is also not established.
Why is this?
Because there is a cause and condition.
The karmic formations perfume the consciousness due to the power of grasping;
Because it is transformed into existence when perfuming is complete.ğŸ”½Among them, karma is defilement, called karmic defilement.
Moreover, because of karma there is defilement, called karmic defilement.
Therefore, karmic defilement is not established.
Chapter 13: Defilement of Birth. The treatise says:
How is the defilement of birth not established?
Because rebirth is not established.

If, in the unstable stage, the mind in the intermediate state is defiled by defiled mental consciousness and takes rebirth, this defiled mental consciousness ceases in the intermediate state, and consciousness combines with the kalala in the mother's womb.

If only mental consciousness combines to take rebirth, and after combining, consciousness relies on this and mental consciousness arises in the mother's womb, then in the mother's womb two mental consciousnesses would arise simultaneously in the same place.
That mental consciousness which combines to take rebirth cannot be established, because mental consciousness always relies on defilement.
Because the object of mental consciousness cannot be obtained.

If this mental consciousness were to unite with the red and white elements, would this united consciousness itself be the seed of everything, or would another consciousness arise based on this consciousness and be the seed of everything?
If that united consciousness itself were the seed of everything, it would be the Älaya consciousness, and you would have to posit a separate name for it, calling it mental consciousness.
If you say that the consciousness that arises based on it is the seed of everything, and that the substance of the support itself is not the seed of everything, this would make no sense.
For this reason, it is established that this united consciousness is not mental consciousness, but is the retributive consciousness, because it is the seed of everything.
The commentary says:
Apart from the Älaya consciousness, the arising of defilements is not possible. This meaning will now be revealed.
The connection at birth is not possible means that the attainment of one's own body is not possible.
The agitated stage refers to the desire realm.
To fall means to die.
The defiled mental consciousness means that the mental consciousness is accompanied by afflictions.
As for receiving birth, it means grasping one's own body. Because that defiled mental consciousness takes rebirth as its object, the intermediate state then ends.

As for coming together, it means the same similarity in formation and destruction. That is to say, because the mental consciousness comes together with the red and white [elements], based on the coming together of the mental consciousness, another mental consciousness arises.

As for the two consciousnesses existing together, it means that at the same time there is the coming together of the mental consciousness and the separate mental consciousness that arises based on it. Because the two consciousnesses exist together at the same time.
Moreover, that coming together of the mental consciousness cannot be established as the mental consciousness.
Why is this?
Because at all times it is defiled and takes something as its support.

That coming together of the mental consciousness takes the defiled mind accompanied by desires and other afflictions as its support, and takes rebirth as its object. Because it is defiled, it is said to be defiled and takes something as its support because it relies on this.
The consciousness that has already entered the womb does not take the defiled as its support, because the substance of the retribution is indeterminate.

As for because what is grasped by mental consciousness cannot be found, what is grasped by mental consciousness can be found, namely various dharmas. This combined consciousness has no object grasped, and therefore it cannot be established as mental consciousness.
The treatise states:

Moreover, after conception, the physical faculties are grasped and sustained. If there is no meaning of obtainability apart from the retributive consciousness, the remaining consciousnesses each have a separate basis and do not firmly abide.
However, the physical faculties do not exist without consciousness.
The commentary states:
After conception means having already obtained a body.

If it were different means apart from the Älaya consciousness, the remaining six consciousnesses each have a separate location and move and change. For example, visual consciousness is only definitely based on the eyes, and in the same way, auditory consciousness and the remaining consciousnesses each have their own bases, such as the ears and other physical faculties.

If there were no Älaya consciousness, and each of these consciousnesses were to grasp and maintain its own basis, then sometimes these consciousnesses would be in motion and not exist, and without grasping and maintaining the eyes and other faculties, they would immediately decay and perish.
The treatise says:
The mutual dependence of consciousness and name-and-form, like two bundles of reeds supporting each other, is not established.
The commentary says:
Now, I wish to show that this is not established.
As the World-Honored One said:
Consciousness is the condition for name-and-form, and name-and-form is the condition for consciousness.
Among them, consciousness is the condition for name means the six groups of consciousness.
It is said that name refers to the four aggregates that are not form. Form refers to kalala.
The consciousness that is the object of name-and-form, if there were no Älaya consciousness, what would it be?
Because it depends on name-and-form, it can continue to arise and not cease.
The treatise says:
If apart from the retributive consciousness, the food of consciousness for sentient beings is not established.
Apart from this result-consciousness, among the six consciousnesses, the function of food is not established for any one consciousness among the sentient beings of the three realms.
The commentary says:
This statement shows the meaning of the failure of consciousness to be food.
The World-Honored One has taught four kinds of food:
1. morsel food, 2. contact, 3. intention, and 4. consciousness.
Morsel food has the characteristic of transformation. Having transformed, it can perform the function of nourishing the body.
Contact has the characteristic of objects. For example, with regard to objects such as form, simply by seeing, etc., it can perform the function of nourishing the body.
Intention has the characteristic of recollection. It simply uses recollection to perform the function of nourishing the body, like a thirsty person seeing water and not dying.

Consciousness has the characteristic of grasping. Because of this grasping, the body can abide. If there were no this consciousness, it would be the same as a dead body, putrid and rotting. Therefore, one should know that consciousness is also called food, because it can perform the function of nourishing the body.

Among them, the food of contact refers to the six consciousnesses, and the food of intention refers to the mind of memory. Since it is said that consciousness is food, it is known that there is another consciousness.

Moreover, it is like in deep sleep, unconsciousness, fainting, and the attainment of cessation, where the six consciousnesses cease. What else is there that sustains the body and prevents it from rotting?
Because if the Älaya consciousness is abandoned, the body would rot.
The treatise says:
If one falls from this [attainment of cessation] and is reborn in a higher tranquil state, the defiled and restless mental consciousness binds one to rebirth there.
This defiled and restless mind in that state, if apart from the Älaya consciousness, its seeds cannot be found.
The commentary says:
It has already been said that rebirth in the restless states is not possible, and now it will be shown that rebirth in the tranquil states is not possible.
Here, rebirth is bound by the defiled consciousness. If in the tranquil states, rebirth is also bound by the defiled and restless [mind].
The defiled [mind] is so called because it is tainted by the afflictions of that state.
The afflictions of that stage refer to attachment to the taste of concentration and so on. This defilement is precisely in the restless stage.
This person dies in the restless stage. Having died, how can the mind of the higher stage manifest?
Since it does not manifest, how can it form rebirth there?

Therefore, it is certain that there must be the Älaya consciousness. Because there is the mind perfumed by that stage since beginningless time, and because by this perfuming the mind of that stage can manifest and form rebirth there.
The treatise says:

Even if one is born in the formless realm, the defiled and wholesome minds, if apart from the consciousness that is the result of the maturation of all seeds, these defiled and wholesome minds would lack seeds and a dwelling place.
The commentary says:
Born in the formless realm refers to liberation from the form realm.
Defiled and wholesome minds refer to the taste of delighting in samÄdhi.
Lacking seeds and a dwelling place means lacking causes and lacking a basis.
There is another meaning:
If there were no seeds, how could they arise?
If there were no abode, how could they abide in dependence?
Because that mind is grasped by the Älaya consciousness, it arises from its own seeds and depends on this consciousness. Because it has a basis, it can continue to abide.
The treatise says:
If the supramundane mind appears in that realm, the remaining mundane minds cease, and one would then be separated from that destiny.
The commentary says:

If the supramundane mind appears in that realm, except for this supramundane mind, the rest are all mundane minds. Because those mundane minds do not exist, one then severs that destiny, which is to attain nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder effortlessly.
Since this is not reasonable, it is not established apart from the Älaya consciousness.
The treatise says:
If the supramundane mind appears in the state of neither perception nor non-perception, depending on the sphere of nothingness, one would then abandon both destinies.
This supramundane consciousness does not rely on the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, nor does it rely on the sphere of nothingness, nor does it rely on the state of nirvana.
The commentary says:

If one is born in the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, sometimes the supramundane mind of the sphere of nothingness appears, because the mind of that sphere is clear and sharp, while the mind of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is dull.
The supramundane mind appears in the state of clear and sharp mind. That supramundane mind does not rely on the first or second sphere, because these two stages are all mundane.
Moreover, the appearance of the mind of a different stage in a different stage of birth does not rely on the two spheres, because the body has a remainder.
If this mind takes nirvana as its support, it is also not established.
If these three kinds of supports are not established in this way, apart from the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna, where does this supramundane mind abide?
The treatise says:

If a person creates good or evil karma, when they are about to die, if they are separated from the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna, the body will either become cold from above or from below, and this will not be possible.
Therefore, if one is separated from the consciousness that is the result of all seeds, the defiled [mind] will also not be possible.
The commentary says:

In this case, if one creates good or evil karma, then there will be a difference in the body becoming cold from above or below, because one who creates good karma ascends, while one who creates evil karma descends.
Therefore, if one does not admit that there is an Älaya-vijÃ±Äna that holds it, how can the body become cold in this way?
Because the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna holds it, it is gradually released from above or below, and wherever it is released, that becomes the corpse, and thus the body becomes cold.
